gov.usgs.anss.edgeoutput

Class TraceBufQueuedListener

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.lang.Thread
      • gov.usgs.anss.edgeoutput.TraceBufQueuedListener
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Runnable

    public class TraceBufQueuedListener
extends java.lang.Thread
    This class listens to a UDP port and broadcast address for TraceBufs queues them into a raw byte queue established at startup. This is a subthread to the TraceBufListener class which is the EdgeThread. That class dequeues the data from this one and processes it into the Edgemom environment. The Solaris Java allowed connection directly to the broadcast address and ensured data came from the right subnet. Linux would not allow this. So we connect to the port wide open from all interfaces and subnet, and check each packet to make sure it comes from the right subnet or discard it. May 2008. DCK 
     These parameters actually come from the TraceBufListener class.  They are arguments to
 the constructor
 -host ip.add.ress Use this broadcast address to listen def=192.168.18.255 (edgewire)
 -port nnnn        Listen for traffic on port nnnn def=40010 (edgewire)
 -dbg              Print details of each packet received.
 Note : a log file will be created in ~/log/tbNNNNN.log?

    • Constructor Detail

      • TraceBufQueuedListener

        public TraceBufQueuedListener(java.lang.String locip,
                      int pt,
                      int maxQueue,
                      int maxLength,
                      EdgeThread parent)
                       throws java.net.UnknownHostException
        Creates a new instance of TraceBufQueuedClient
        Parameters:
        locip - The IP address (broadcast address) to listen on
        pt - The port number to listen for UDP packets
        maxQueue - Number of messages to reserve space for in queue
        maxLength - Maximum record length for these messages
        parent - The parent EdgeThread to use for logging.
        Throws:
        java.net.UnknownHostException - if the locip does not make sense
